title: Erdős Problem #424: Sequence Generated by a_i · a_j − 1
description: Start with {2,3}, iteratively append a_i · a_j − 1. Does the resulting set have positive density? No element ≡ 1 (mod 3) appears, so density ≤ 2/3. OEIS A005244. Open.

references: Guy E31: Unsolved Problems in Number Theory

sections.title: Main Conjecture
sections.summary: Does generatedSet have positive lower density?

overview.historicalContext: Erdős posed this in 1977. The sequence a_i · a_j − 1 starting from {2,3} grows in a complex way. It appears as E31 in Guy's book and Problem 63 on Green's open problems list.
overview.problemStatement: Start with a₁ = 2, a₂ = 3. Iteratively append all a_i · a_j − 1 (i ≠ j). Does the set of integers that eventually appear have positive density?
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize the generation process, define the full generated set, and state the positive-density conjecture. The mod 3 obstruction provides an upper density bound of 2/3.
keyInsights: No element is ≡ 1 (mod 3), by induction on the generation
The set is closed under (x,y) ↦ xy − 1 for distinct elements
Appears as Guy E31 and Green Problem 63

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #424 asks whether the set generated from {2,3} by the operation a_i · a_j − 1 has positive density. The mod 3 obstruction caps density at 2/3, and the question of positive density remains open.
conclusion.implications: A resolution would illuminate the density properties of multiplicatively generated integer sequences.
openQuestions: If so, what is the density?
How does the growth rate of new elements per generation behave?
